content: How can I help you today?

I’ve been really struggling to stay focused lately. My wife and I are dealing with a lot at home… our son is having some serious behavioral issues, and it feels like everything is starting to fall apart. It’s affecting my marriage, my work, and even my ability to enjoy time with my daughter. I don’t really know what to do anymore.

That sounds like such an overwhelming situation to navigate right now. It must be difficult trying to balance all of that while also feeling like it's taking a toll on so many parts of your life. How have you been managing things so far?

Honestly, I don't think I've been managing it well at all. I just feel stressed all the time. I try to be present and help at home, but it's like nothing I do makes a difference. It’s exhausting, and I end up shutting down more often than not.

That sounds incredibly draining—to feel like you're giving so much, but not seeing the progress you hope for. It takes a lot of courage to open up about feeling this way. When you do find yourself shutting down, what does that usually look like for you?

I just get quiet and distant. I'll sit in the same room as my wife or kids, but it's like I'm not even there. I zone out or turn to my phone for distraction. I know it’s not helping anyone, but I just don’t have the energy to engage sometimes.

It sounds like you're feeling stuck—like you're physically present but emotionally drained, and using distractions just to keep going. It makes sense that without the energy to engage, it’s hard to show up how you might want to for your family. What do you think would need to change for you to feel a little more connected or less overwhelmed?

I'm not really sure, to be honest. Maybe if we could figure out what's going on with my son and how to help him, that might ease some of the stress. But even thinking about that feels overwhelming—we’ve already tried so many things that haven’t worked. I just feel stuck.

It sounds like you're carrying a lot of uncertainty and frustration, especially when it feels like you've been trying so hard without seeing the changes you'd hoped for. Even though things feel so heavy right now, it’s clear how much you care about your son and your family. What would it look like for you to take just one small step toward understanding what might help with your son?

Maybe it’d mean reaching out to someone who might have more experience with this kind of thing, like a counselor or a specialist for kids. But honestly, I’m so skeptical about that kind of stuff. It’s hard to believe someone else could actually help when we’ve already tried so much on our own.

It's understandable to feel skeptical, especially after putting so much effort in and not seeing the progress you hoped for. It takes a lot to even consider reaching out for help when you're feeling burnt out. What do you think holds you back the most from taking that step, even just to explore the possibility?

I guess it's the fear that it won't actually change anything—that we'll go through all this effort, and it’ll just be one more thing that doesn’t work. Plus, I feel like it’s my responsibility as his dad to figure it out, and asking for help feels like I’ve failed somehow.

It sounds like there’s a lot of pressure you’re putting on yourself—feeling like, as a dad, you should have all the answers. And the idea of trying again, only to risk disappointment, must feel pretty daunting. You really seem to want what’s best for your son, and it’s clear that you care deeply about being a strong parent for him. How do you think it would feel if you let go of the idea that asking for help means failing?

If I could let go of that, I think it might be a bit of a relief. But it’s definitely hard—it’s ingrained in me to think I’m supposed to fix this on my own. Maybe I’ve just never looked at asking for help as something that could actually make me a stronger parent.

That’s such an insightful realization—recognizing that reaching out for support could actually be a strength rather than a weakness. It’s not easy to reframe something so deeply ingrained. What do you think would change for you and your family if you allowed yourself to view asking for help as part of being the parent you want to be?

I guess it might take some of the weight off of me and give us a better chance at figuring out how to help my son. If it could ease some of the tension at home and help me be more present with my wife and daughter, that would mean a lot. It’s scary, but I can see how it might be worth trying.

It sounds like you’re starting to see how taking that step—though scary—might actually bring some relief and create space for connection with the people you care about. It’s clear how much your family means to you, and it’s a big deal to recognize that asking for help could be a part of strengthening those relationships. Is there anything else on your mind that you’d like to explore before we talk about what that first step could look like?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
